children.name: make
children.definition: sb do sthkhiến ai làm gì/làm cho ai làm gì
examples: Sarah’s very funny. Her jokes always make me laugh.
The things she said make me wonder if she is in some kind of trouble.
The smell was so bad it almost made me throw up.

children.name: be made to do sth
examples: I was made to wait for over an hour.

children.name: lead
children.definition: sb to do sth to be the thing that makes sb do sth, especially when this process takes some time: dẫn đến ai đó phải làm gì
examples: What led you to take up teaching as a career?
It was my interest in gardens that led me to study biology.

children.name: lead sb to believe
examples: The negative publicity has already led many to believe that Tompkins is guilty.

children.name: induce
children.definition: sb to do sth formal to make someone choose to do something:khiến ai làm gì
examples: ▪ Whatever induced her to buy such an expensive car?
▪ The state advertises a great deal to induce its citizens to buy lottery tickets.

children.name: motivate
children.definition: if sth motivates sb to do sth, it makes them want to do it - use this especially to talk about the reasons why people do things that are very good, very bad, or very dangerous:động viên, khuyến khích

children.name: motivate sb to do sth
examples: I don’t know what motivates people to commit such crimes.

children.name: be motivated by sth
examples: He was motivated by a desire to help his fellow man.
Many in the Asian community feel that the police actions were motivated by racial bias.

children.name: prompt
children.definition: sb to do sth to be the thing that makes you to do sth, especially sth you have been thinking of doing for some time: thúc đẩy, thúc dục
examples: ▪ It was reading his book that prompted me to write to him.
▪ What exactly prompted him to call you in the middle of the night?

children.name: to force sb to do sth
force
children.definition: to make sb do sth they do not want to do. Used when people or situations make you do something: ép buộc
examples: You don’t have to come if you don’t want to. Nobody’s forcing you.

children.name: force sb to do sth
examples: Women’s organizations are trying to force the government to appoint more women to senior positions.

children.name: force sb into (doing) sth
examples: Her parents are trying to force her into marrying a man she hardly knows.
I had never thought of buying an insurance policy, and I wasn’t going to be forced into it by some young salesman.

children.name: force sb out of
examples: Eddie feels that he was forced out of his job in order to make way for a younger man.

children.name: make
children.definition: to force sb to do sth that theydo not wantto do.Makeislessformaland more common thanforcein everyday English: bắt, ép buộc
examples: ▪ I really didn’t want to go, but she made me.

children.name: make sb do sth
examples: ▪ I wanted to watch the film, but Dad made me do my homework.
▪ Karen made him promise never to discuss the subject again.

children.name: put pressure on
children.definition: to keep trying to persuade sb to do something, for example by saying that it is theirdutyor that itwill help other people: gây áp lực, ép buộc

children.name: put pressure on sb to do sth
examples: ▪ Our parents were putting pressure on us to get married.
▪ Advertising puts pressure on parents to work long hours, in order to buy things that their children don’t need.

children.name: pressurize
children.definition: /pressuriseBritish /pressureAmerican  to try to make sb do sth by persuading them verystronglyand making them feel that they should do it: gây áp lực, gây sức ép
examples: ▪ I’ll get this done as soon as I can -- just don’t pressure me, OK!
▪ If she feels you’re trying to pressurize her, she won’t do it.

children.name: pressurize/pressure somebody into doing sth
examples: ▪ School children are often pressurized into studying very hard from an early age by their parents.
▪ The committee pressured him into resigning.

children.name: pressure sb to do sth
examples: ▪ Her boyfriend is pressuring her to have an abortion.

children.name: push
children.definition: to strongly encourage sb to do sth: thúc dục

children.name: push sb to do sth
examples: ▪ My parents keep pushing me to get a good job.

children.name: push sb into (doing) sth
examples: ▪ Don’t let them push you into a making a decision before you’re ready.
▪ Are you sure you want to marry me? I don’t want to push you into anything.

children.name: browbeat
children.definition: to force sb to do what you want them to do by repeatedly asking them to do it until they finally agree: mồi chài
examples: ▪ The salesman tried browbeating me but it didn’t work.

children.name: browbeat sb into (doing) sth
examples: ▪ The miners were browbeaten into working in a part of the mine that the company knew to be dangerous.
▪ I really didn’t want to make this speech -- I was browbeaten into it by my colleagues.

children.name: emotional blackmail
children.definition: an attempt to force sb to do sth, by making them feel guilty for not doing it:
examples: She’s always using emotional blackmail and playing on other people’s feelings.
Any relationship that has to depend on emotional blackmail can’t be a healthy one.

children.name: be breathing down sb’s neck
children.definition: bebreathing down sb’s neck informal if sb is breathing down your neck about sth, they keep asking you to do it in order to make you do it sooner:
examples: ▪ I’m already really busy today, and now Paul’s breathing down my neck saying he wants the Paris deal completed.

children.name: have sb breathing down your neck
examples: ▪ We’d better start sending out those letters soon -- I’ve had the sales manager breathing down my neck about it all week.

children.name: be on sb’s back
children.definition: informal to be trying to make sb do sth they do not want to do, especially by telling them several times to do it: đốc thúc
examples: ▪ Nick knew that the coach would be on his back if he missed another training session.be
on sb’s back about
▪ Aunt Mimi was always on his back about him ‘wasting time playing that silly guitar’.

children.name: to force sb do sth by using threats or violence
compel
children.definition: formalto make sb do sth by using force or official power: ép buộc

children.name: compel sb to do sth
examples: ▪ All the young men in the area were compelled to work in the quarries and coal mines.
▪ The attorney general has the right to compel witnesses to appear in court.

children.name: force
children.definition: /fɔːʳs/  bắt ép
examples: ▪ If you don’t comply I’m afraid we’ll have to force you.

children.name: force sb to do sth
examples: ▪ Thieves had tied him up and forced him to lie on the floor.
▪ All the hostages were forced to hand over their passports.

children.name: force sb into (doing) sth
examples: ▪ She claimed she was forced to take part in the robbery by her husband.

children.name: make
children.definition: /meɪk/  to force sb to do sth by using violence or threats.Makeislessformaland more common thanforcein everyday English: : khiến
examples: ▪ I didn’t want to take part in the attack but the soldiers made me.

children.name: make sb do sth
examples: ▪ They made sales staff open the safe.

children.name: be made to do sth
examples: ▪ The couple were made to hand over all their money and jewellery.

children.name: coerce
children.definition: written to force someone to do something that they do not want to do by threatening that something bad might happen to them if they do not do it: đe doạ
examples: ▪ Ray withdrew his confession, saying that he had been coerced by the police.
coercion[U] sự đe doạ
▪ When peaceful methods of persuasion had failed, the government tried using coercion.

children.name: coerce somebody into doing sth
examples: ▪ The mine owners coerced the workers into going back to work, by threatening to close down the mines completely.
▪ Officials coerced peasants into voting for the government candidates.

children.name: coerce sb to do sth
examples: ▪ The company paid the workers the minimum rate of $4.86 an hour, but coerced some to give back half their pay in cash.

children.name: bully
children.definition: informal to force sb to do sth by shouting at them, treating them badly, or using threats: bắt nạt, đe dọa
examples: ▪ Don’t let the salesman bully you -- it’s your choice.

children.name: bully sb into doing sth
examples: ▪ If you try and bully him into giving you the money he’s sure to say no -- you should try and persuade him gently.

children.name: bully sb into sth
examples: ▪ Ben didn’t want to study law, but his father bullied him into it by threatening to cut off his allowance.

children.name: use force
children.definition: /ˌjuːz ˈfɔːʳs/  if someone uses force, they hit, shoot, or use other forms of violence against people in order to make them do something or stop them from doing something: sử dụng vũ lực
examples: ▪ The regime was quite willing to use force and terror against its enemies.
▪ The law permits every citizen to use reasonable force to defend themselves or their property.

children.name: use force against sử dụng vụ lực với
examples: ▪ The police have recently had to defend their policy of using force against rioters.

children.name: strongarm tactics
children.definition: /methods violence or the threat of violence, used to force sb to do sth: chiến thuật, biện pháp mạnh
examples: ▪ The police have been accused of using strongarm tactics when breaking up strikes and public demonstrations.

children.name: use strongarm tactics/methods to do sth
examples: ▪ More and more credit companies are using strongarm methods to collect debts.

children.name: under duress
children.definition: if sb does sth under duress, they only agree to do it because they have been threatened, not because they want to do it: vị cưỡng ép
examples: The defendants claimed that their confessions were made under duress.
Judge Mershon ruled that the agreement was signed under duress, and was therefore null and void.

children.name: to be forced to do sth because of a bad situation
force
children.definition: ép buộc

children.name: force somebody to do sth
examples: ▪ They had so little money that they were forced to sell the farm.
▪ They were halfway up the mountain, when the weather became so bad that they were forced to turn back.

children.name: force somebody into sth
examples: ▪ Here, girls are often forced into prostitution because they have no other means of earning money.

children.name: drive
children.definition: if sth, especially sb else’s behaviour drives sb to do sth, it has such a bad effect on them that it forces them to take extreme action: khiến cho

children.name: drive sb to do sth
examples: ▪ At the trial, she claimed that years of abuse from her violent husband had driven her to kill him.

children.name: drive sb to despair/desperation etc
examples: ▪ Many farmers claim that they have been driven to desperation by the latest blow to the industry.

children.name: drive sb to drinkmake someone drink alcohol all the time in order to forget their situation khiến ai đó uống rượu
examples: ▪ This job’s enough to drive anyone to drink!

children.name: drive somebody into doing sth
examples: ▪ Her mother’s continual nagging drove her into running away from home.

children.name: no choice
children.definition: have / have no optionC1 to be forced to do sth because it is the only thing you can do even though you may not want to do it: không còn lựa chọn khác
examples: ▪ We had to leave them there. We had no choice.
▪ Firefighters said they had to knock down the remaining walls - they have no other option.

children.name: leave sb with no choice/ option
examples: ▪ The business was failing, and in the end we had to close it down. We were left with no choice.

children.name: leave sb with no choice/option but to do sth
examples: ▪ You leave me with no option but to resign.

children.name: compel
children.definition: sb to do sth formal if a bad situation compels sb to do sth they do not want to do, they are forced to do it because they feel there is nothing else they can do: buộc ai đó làm việc gì
examples: The high cost of materials will compel manufacturers to increase their prices.
These people are compelled by poverty to commit crime.

children.name: be condemned to
children.definition: to be forced to accept a very unhappy situation because there is nothing else you can do : bị lên án, xử tội

children.name: be condemned to sth
examples: ▪ The island was condemned to centuries of colonial rule.
▪ The accident condemned her to a lifetime of pain and disability.

children.name: be condemned to do sth
examples: ▪ The rich lived in luxury while thousands were condemned to live a life of poverty and despair.

children.name: to force sb to accept sth they do not want
force sth on
children.definition: sb áp đặt lên
examples: He thinks that just because he’s the head of department he can force his opinions on everybody.
You shouldn’t blame your father -- the decision was forced on him by his situation.
Elaine kept forcing drinks on him all evening, and he wondered if she was trying to seduce him.

children.name: impose
children.definition: if you impose your ideas and beliefs on other people, you try to force them to have the same ideas and beliefs as you: áp đặt
examples: Within days of being appointed office manager he had imposed his own working methods.
imposition[U] sự áp đặt
There has been widespread protest against the imposition of religious teaching in schools.

children.name: impose sth on sb
examples: Teachers should try to avoid imposing their own beliefs on their students.

children.name: inflict sth on
children.definition: to force sb to accept sth that causes them harm or suffering: bắt phải chịu
examples: As time progressed, the king inflicted harsher and harsher measures on the people.
The new policy means that even higher bills will be inflicted on the taxpayer.

children.name: foist sth on
children.definition: sb to get rid of a thing or piece of work that you do not want by giving it to sb else: đùn đẩy
examples: It’s no use trying to foist your work on me.

children.name: foist sth off on to sb
examples: He’s always trying to foist the children off on to me while he goes out and enjoys himself.

children.name: pressure
children.definition: an attempt to persuade someone by using influence, arguments, or threats :
examples: They areputting pressure onpeople to vote yes.
be/come under pressure to do something
The minister was under pressure to resign.
be/come under pressure from somebody (to do something)
I was under pressure from my parents to become a teacher.
The Labour government came under pressure from the trade unions.
pressure for
Pressure for change has become urgent.
pressure on
the pressure on all of us to keep slim
Heexerts pressure onhis kids to get them to do as he wants.
You must nevergive in to pressure.

children.name: put pressure on somebody
examples: We’ve decided to set up a campaign to put pressure on the Government.

children.name: exert pressure on somebodyformal
children.definition: put pressure on them
examples: They exerted pressure on their colleagues to vote for the change.

children.name: bring pressure to bear on somebody
children.definition: put pressure on them
examples: These groups have brought pressure to bear on the government.

children.name: put somebody under pressure
children.definition: put a lot of pressure on them
examples: They were put under pressure to sign confessions.

children.name: be under pressure
examples: Apple growers are under pressure from the public to use fewer chemicals.

children.name: come under pressure
examples: The new Prime Minister has already come under pressure from the opposition to call an election.

children.name: bow to pressure
children.definition: alsogive in to pressure
examples: (= do what people want you to do )He eventually gave in to pressure and resigned.

children.name: respond to pressure
children.definition: do something as a result of pressure
examples: The government responded to this pressure and modified the Bill.

children.name: strong/intense pressure
examples: There was strong pressure for a statement from the President.

children.name: considerable pressure
examples: Shopkeepers are under considerable pressure to work on Sundays.

children.name: increasing/mounting pressure
examples: There was increasing pressure on the Chancellor to cut petrol tax.

children.name: public/popular pressure
children.definition: pressure from the public
examples: He faces mounting public pressure to resign.

children.name: political pressure
examples: We did not make this recommendation because of political pressure.

children.name: diplomatic pressure
children.definition: pressure from other countries' governments
examples: The announcement of a ceasefire came after intense diplomatic pressure from the US.

children.name: impose
children.definition: verbFORCE

children.name: reduce sb to sth
children.definition: reducesbtosthphrasal verb

children.name: If you are reduced to doing something, you are forced to do it because you have no other choice
examples: _I'd run out of cigarettes and was reduced to smoking the butts left in the ashtrays.
